observationText: The Nf1 heterozygous mutant minipigs developed cafe au lait macules (CALMs) from birth, one of the most common phenotypes in NF1 patients.
A subset of the Nf1 heterozygous mutant minipigs developed neurofibromas around 4 months of age, corresponding to puberty.
One out of seven Nf1 heterozygous mutant minipigs developed optic pathway glioma (OPG), exhibiting a mass involving the optic chiasm.
Melanocytes and Schwann cells from the Nf1 heterozygous mutant minipigs underwent spontaneous loss of heterozygosity (LOH), a critical step in disease progression also observed in NF1 patients.
The Nf1 heterozygous mutant minipigs exhibited variable expression of NF1 phenotypes, with the size and number of cafe au lait macules (CALMs) varying greatly between animals.
The Nf1 heterozygous mutant minipigs reached puberty at around 5-6 months of age, similar to the timing of neurofibroma development in human NF1 patients.
The Nf1 heterozygous mutant minipigs exhibited a lifespan of up to 15 years, allowing for longitudinal studies of NF1 disease features in both pediatric and adult populations.
The Nf1 heterozygous mutant minipigs were dosed orally with a small-molecule inhibitor currently in clinical development for NF1, which led to a targeted reduction in Ras signaling.
The Nf1 heterozygous mutant minipigs grew to a size of 180-220 pounds, roughly the size of an adult human, making them suitable for advanced imaging studies on human-sized instruments.
The Nf1 heterozygous mutant minipigs exhibited germ line transmission of the mutant NF1 allele with Mendelian frequency, with no evidence of reduced fitness compared to wild-type littermates.
